div.div: Delavsko-kmetski list je med letoma 1924 in 1926 predstavljal legalno tedensko glasilo tedaj ilegalne Komunistične partije Jugoslavije na Slovenskem. Izhajal je v Ljubljani, njegov predhodnik je bil list Glas Svobode. Med vidnejšimi sodelavci lista lahko naštejemo Dragotina Gustinčiča, Dušana Kermavnerja, Franceta in Mileta Klopčiča ter Lovra Kuharja. Okrog glasila se je oblikovala legalna politična skupina Delavsko kmetski republikanski blok, ki se je zavzemala za samostojno slovensko delavsko kmečko republiko in se borila proti politiki gospodarskega zatiranja ter za svobodo političnega delovanja. V posamičnih številkah lista lahko spremljamo zaplete v kriznem obdobju za Komunistično partijo Jugoslavije v Sloveniji, leta 1925 namreč prihaja do združevanja strokovnih organizacij. List je bil aprila 1926 prepovedan, vsebinsko pa se je nadaljeval v tedniku Enotnost.

Between 1924 and 1926 Delavsko-kmetski list (Workers and Peasants Paper) represented a legal weekly publication of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia, illegal at the time. It was published in Ljubljana and it superseded the newspaper Glas Svobode (Voice of Freedom). The more prominent contributors of the paper include Dragotin Gustinčič, Dušan Kermavner, France and Mile Klopčič, and Lovro Kuhar. A legal political group called the Republican Bloc of Workers and Peasants formed around the paper, arguing for an independent Slovenian republic of workers and peasants, opposing the policy of economic repression, and supporting the freedom of political activities. In the individual issues of the paper we can follow the complications during the period critical for the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia – because in 1925 the merging of expert organisations took place. In April 1926 the paper was forbidden, but essentially its work continued in the Enotnost (Unity) weekly.

Med vidnejšimi sodelavci lista lahko naštejemo Dragotina Gustinčiča, Dušana Kermavnerja, Franceta in Mileta Klopčiča ter Lovra Kuharja. Okrog glasila se je oblikovala legalna politična skupina Delavsko kmetski republikanski blok, ki se je zavzemala za samostojno slovensko delavsko kmečko republiko in se borila proti politiki gospodarskega zatiranja ter za svobodo političnega delovanja. V posamičnih številkah lista lahko spremljamo zaplete v kriznem obdobju za Komunistično partijo Jugoslavije v Sloveniji, leta 1925 namreč prihaja do združevanja strokovnih organizacij. List je bil aprila 1926 prepovedan, vsebinsko pa se je nadaljeval v tedniku Enotnost.

Between 1924 and 1926 Delavsko-kmetski list (Workers and Peasants Paper) represented a legal weekly publication of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia, illegal at the time. It was published in Ljubljana and it superseded the newspaper Glas Svobode (Voice of Freedom). The more prominent contributors of the paper include Dragotin Gustinčič, Dušan Kermavner, France and Mile Klopčič, and Lovro Kuhar. A legal political group called the Republican Bloc of Workers and Peasants formed around the paper, arguing for an independent Slovenian republic of workers and peasants, opposing the policy of economic repression, and supporting the freedom of political activities. In the individual issues of the paper we can follow the complications during the period critical for the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia – because in 1925 the merging of expert organisations took place. In April 1926 the paper was forbidden, but essentially its work continued in the Enotnost (Unity) weekly.

Med vidnejšimi sodelavci lista lahko naštejemo Dragotina Gustinčiča, Dušana Kermavnerja, Franceta in Mileta Klopčiča ter Lovra Kuharja. Okrog glasila se je oblikovala legalna politična skupina Delavsko kmetski republikanski blok, ki se je zavzemala za samostojno slovensko delavsko kmečko republiko in se borila proti politiki gospodarskega zatiranja ter za svobodo političnega delovanja. V posamičnih številkah lista lahko spremljamo zaplete v kriznem obdobju za Komunistično partijo Jugoslavije v Sloveniji, leta 1925 namreč prihaja do združevanja strokovnih organizacij. List je bil aprila 1926 prepovedan, vsebinsko pa se je nadaljeval v tedniku Enotnost.

Between 1924 and 1926 Delavsko-kmetski list (Workers and Peasants Paper) represented a legal weekly publication of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia, illegal at the time. It was published in Ljubljana and it superseded the newspaper Glas Svobode (Voice of Freedom). The more prominent contributors of the paper include Dragotin Gustinčič, Dušan Kermavner, France and Mile Klopčič, and Lovro Kuhar. A legal political group called the Republican Bloc of Workers and Peasants formed around the paper, arguing for an independent Slovenian republic of workers and peasants, opposing the policy of economic repression, and supporting the freedom of political activities. In the individual issues of the paper we can follow the complications during the period critical for the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia – because in 1925 the merging of expert organisations took place. In April 1926 the paper was forbidden, but essentially its work continued in the Enotnost (Unity) weekly.

Med vidnejšimi sodelavci lista lahko naštejemo Dragotina Gustinčiča, Dušana Kermavnerja, Franceta in Mileta Klopčiča ter Lovra Kuharja. Okrog glasila se je oblikovala legalna politična skupina Delavsko kmetski republikanski blok, ki se je zavzemala za samostojno slovensko delavsko kmečko republiko in se borila proti politiki gospodarskega zatiranja ter za svobodo političnega delovanja. V posamičnih številkah lista lahko spremljamo zaplete v kriznem obdobju za Komunistično partijo Jugoslavije v Sloveniji, leta 1925 namreč prihaja do združevanja strokovnih organizacij. List je bil aprila 1926 prepovedan, vsebinsko pa se je nadaljeval v tedniku Enotnost.

Between 1924 and 1926 Delavsko-kmetski list (Workers and Peasants Paper) represented a legal weekly publication of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia, illegal at the time. It was published in Ljubljana and it superseded the newspaper Glas Svobode (Voice of Freedom). The more prominent contributors of the paper include Dragotin Gustinčič, Dušan Kermavner, France and Mile Klopčič, and Lovro Kuhar. A legal political group called the Republican Bloc of Workers and Peasants formed around the paper, arguing for an independent Slovenian republic of workers and peasants, opposing the policy of economic repression, and supporting the freedom of political activities. In the individual issues of the paper we can follow the complications during the period critical for the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Slovenia – because in 1925 the merging of expert organisations took place. In April 1926 the paper was forbidden, but essentially its work continued in the Enotnost (Unity) weekly.
